Keywords: Nanomaterials Environmental fate Hazard Risk scoring
A B S T R A C T
Engineered nanomaterials (ENM) have a widespread presence in human life and are components of many products and applications. This warrants an easy and fast evaluation of potential environmental risks. However, so far this is hampered by the multitude of different nanomaterials on the markets in addition to the many variations in form, size and surface modifications. Testing of each variation of ENM is not manageable, and hence the development and application of fast risk screening tools for ENMs is discussed.
Here, we present the development of a scoring scheme with regard to ENM environmental risks under consideration of the two compartments water and soil. It allows for the ranking of ENM according to their environmental fate and hazard by taking into account criteria that are meaningful and relevant for ENM. The selection of the criteria is based on conceptual considerations, existing knowledge, and experimental work including transport and transformation studies as well as aquatic and terrestrial toxicity tests.
The allocation of the ENM to the scores informs on the potential for transport and transformation and the hazard potential. Fate and hazard scores are subsequently combined into one risk score (1–10 for aquatic compartment, 1–7 for terrestrial compartment). The risk score has the intention to indicate which ENM may need prioritization for further action, i.e. with regard to the degree of detail for further testing or modelling.
The applicability and consistency of the scoring schemes were assessed by taking different chemical species (e.g. of Ag, TiO2, SiO2, Cu, Fe) of ENM in various modifications (e.g. different shapes and coatings) into account. In conclusion, the established scoring schemes were found to be applicable to rank ENM according to their environmental fate and hazard potential, and thus to their environmental risk potential.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Risk assessment for engineered nanomaterials (ENM) is of high importance. Many tools, approaches, and frameworks for the evaluation of risk have been developed within the last decade. Numerous publications deal either with the concept itself (e.g. (Bleeker et al., 2014; Collier et al., 2015; Hansen et al., 2014; Powers et al., 2012) or with an evaluative overview on the advantages and challenges (Bos et al., 2015; Grieger et al., 2012; Hristozov et al., 2016; Hristozov et al., 2012; Scott-Fordsmand et al., 2017) These approaches differ with respect to complexity, requirements for input data, and use of assumptions and modelling, in particular for predicting ENM environmental concentrations and fate (Gottschalk and Nowack, 2011; Gottschalk et al., 2010a; Gottschalk et al., 2010b; Gottschalk et al., 2013; Meesters
et al., 2014; Sun et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2016; Wang and Nowack, 2018). Many of them are highly sophisticated and aim at a full risk assessment (Arts et al., 2015; Jantunen et al., 2018). All approaches share the need for a high amount of input data to obtain robust results or for well–founded assumptions which is both time- and cost intensive to achieve.
With a risk screening ENM of highest risk potential can be identified at a step where only reduced information on environmental fate and effect is available. Obviously, various risk screening methods for ENM exist, many of them aiming at occupational and human health risk. In Arvidsson et al. (2016), e.g., 20 different methods were evaluated. Prominent conclusions were: “First, the further development of screening risk assessment methods focusing on environmental risks is warranted. The risk screening has the potential to inform researchers, developers and producers of nanomaterials on potential risks at an early stage in development (e.g. for safe-by-design approaches).
Both, the cited recommendations and the “early warning signs”method are the basis for the herein published work. The aim is to provide a simple yet informative environmental risk screening method for ENM. The “early warning signs”-method comprises assessment criteria which are both, qualitative (novelty of the product, potentially irreversible action) and quantitative (persistency, bioaccumulation, readily dispersed in the environment). Each of these criteria is evaluated separately on a “YES”/“NO” –basis (i.e. the criterion is fulfilled/ not fulfilled). The number of warning signs that are fulfilled triggers the environmental risk priority and thus, determines the further actions.
In further developing the “early warning signs”-method, the set of criteria is extended, which describe environmental fate and hazard of synthetic nanomaterials. First, the fate and hazard criteria are assessed separately. Depending on the number of criteria fulfilled, fate scores and hazard scores are given. These scores represent the environmental fate potential and hazard potential. In a second step, the fate and hazard scores are combined into a risk score to yield an environmental risk ranking or risk prioritization. Similar concepts have been applied successfully in the context of an environmental hazard ranking and prioritization of new and existing chemicals (Herrchen et al., 1993; Klein et al., 1988; Weiss et al., 1988). As far as possible, cut-off values were derived to allow for the decision between “YES” and “NO” (the criterion is fulfilled/not fulfilled). The derivation was achieved on the basis of a fairly comprehensive data set of up to 25 ENMs, which was also used in a case study to test the applicability of the developed scoring scheme for consistent rankings.

sections.heading: 2.1. Conceptual approach
sections.text:
First, the hypothesis was tested whether ENM intrinsic physicochemical (PC) properties allow for a prediction of their environmental fate and behaviour, and thus present a sufficiently reliable and precise basis for the fate scoring. Such a hypothesis presupposes unequivocal dependencies of PC properties and processes describing the fate and behaviour in the environment. Processes are, for example, ENM agglomeration, transformation and movement in soil and water. Herein under, these various processes are subsumed under the term “fate criteria”.
A comprehensive evaluation of the compiled literature as well as the experimentally determined data clearly showed the absence of any significant correlation between single PC properties and fate criteria. For the criterion “dissolution in aqueous media”, this is exemplarily presented in the Supporting Information (SI) 2 in Figs. S1–S4. In total, for the verification and refinement of the scoring approach a dataset of a minimum of 18 ENM was used. A summary of all experimental procedures and the data sets obtained is available in SI 2. The lack of simple correlations might be due to the high complexity and variability of the systems that were analyzed. This problem is well known for “traditional chemicals” as well (Arvidsson et al., 2016).
In conclusion, PC properties were not used for the fate scoring of ENM. Alternatively, a pragmatic approach directly starting from a comprehensive set of fate criteria was followed. Two environmental compartments were considered, namely water and soil. This was achieved by:
1. Selection of relevant fate criteria.
2. Description of criteria by “YES” (the criterion is fulfilled) and “NO” (the criterion is not fulfilled) and transformation of “YES” and “NO” into numerical scores. 3. Suggestion of trigger values to enable ENM allocation to “YES” and “NO”. 4. Aggregation of all criteria by their score combination to result in the final fate score.

sections.heading: 2.2. Fate scoring for the aquatic compartment
2.2.1. Selection of relevant fate criteria
sections.text: For simplification, in this first approach the water phase only, i.e. without sediment was considered. This was to exclude highly complex processes at the boundary layer between water and sediment like adsorption/desorption, and resuspension, on which reliable information is rather scarce. Furthermore, a harmonized approach both, for fate and hazard scoring was intended. The latter puts emphasis on aquatic organisms (ref. chapter 3.2). The focus was on those processes, which might alter the ENM concentration in the water phase. Hence, in the water compartment, the fate criteria “transformation by dissolution”, “transformation by agglomeration” as well as “chemical transformation” are considered as being the relevant ones. Biological degradation is not accounted for in this very first approach. The biological degradation is not easily describable as it often takes place at the surface water/sediment interface layer and is accompanied by sorption/desorption processes.

sections.heading: 2.2.2. Description of criteria by “YES” and “NO” and transformation into numerical scores
sections.text:
The selected fate criteria were described by either “YES” (≙ criterion is fulfilled, the process occurs) or “NO” (≙ criterion is not fulfilled, the process does not occur). These “YES”/“NO” descriptions are transformed into the numerical scores “0” and “1”. Score “0” is given in case of fulfillment of the criterion as this results in a reduction of ENM concentration in the aqueous phase. Score “1” is given in case the criterion is not fulfilled and thus, no reduction of the ENM concentration occurs (Table 1).
2.2.3. Suggestion of trigger values to enable ENM allocation to “YES” and “NO”
Furthermore, trigger values were suggested for each of the criteria to be able to decide for “YES” or “NO”. These triggers were selected pragmatically either by expert knowledge or based on the largest possible data set available, which is based on literature data and own experiments.
The trigger value for the criterion “transformation by dissolution” is based on experiments analyzing the ENM solubility in deionized (DI) water. By using this data we have to take in mind, that the dissolution in the relevant compartment can be different (higher or lower), dependent on the oxic or anoxic conditions, pH and chelating agents (Lowry et al., 2012; Schwabe et al., 2014).
For the criterion “transformation by agglomeration” data analyzing the change in the agglomeration state in DI Water (using e.g. DLS or SEM) and changes in the concentration directly and after 24 h in the supernatant of a sample were used to determine the agglomeration behaviour of the ENM in the water compartment. A decreasing concentration in the supernatant is an indication of an instable dispersion and sedimentation of the particles. The data in DI water are a worstcase approach as in DI water for most of the tested ENM a higher stability due to lower agglomeration and sedimentation is expected compared to natural water.
If no information about the agglomeration behaviour in the first 24 h were available (DLS/SEM data and data about the concentration in the supernatant directly after dispersion and after 24 h), data of the zeta potential were used to deduce the stability of the ENM in water. As worst case approach zeta potential values above±20mV were defined
as stable. The decision as to whether chemical transformation occurs needs a case-by-case expert judgement.

sections.heading: 2.2.4. Criteria aggregation by score combination
sections.text: The scores “0” or “1” for the criteria “transformation by dissolution”, “transformation by agglomeration”, and “chemical transformation” are further combined into one single numerical fate score. This can be achieved by a simple combination exercise. The final fate scores are numbered “1” to “4” by definition and not by mathematical addition of the values “0” and “1” each for the criteria. The higher the final score number, the higher the expected amount of ENM in the water system (see Fig. 1).

sections.heading: 2.4. Fate scoring for the terrestrial compartment
2.4.1. Selection of relevant fate criteria
sections.text: The soil compartment is seen as an open system, which allows for transport processes. Thus, “chemical and biological transformation”, “transformation by dissolution in soil”, and “mobility” are the selected processes (i.e. criteria), which alter the ENM concentration in soil.

sections.heading: 2.4.2. Description of criteria by “YES” and “NO” and transformation into numerical scores
sections.text:
In concordance to the approach taken for the water system, the selected fate criteria were allocated to either “YES” or “NO”. “YES” (Score “0”) means that the criterion is fulfilled; the process occurs and results in a reduction of ENM concentration in the compartment. “NO” (Score “1”) means that the criterion is not fulfilled, the process does not occur and does not result in a reduction of ENM concentration.
2.4.3. Suggestion of trigger values to enable ENM allocation to “YES” and “NO”
Likewise, trigger values were pragmatically suggested as summarized in Table 3. The suggested values are open for further discussion and modifications (“living values”).

sections.heading: 2.4.4. Criteria aggregation by score combination
sections.text: The scores “0” and “1”, respectively, for the criteria “chemical/ biological transformation”, “transformation by dissolution”, and “mobility” are further combined into one single numerical fate score. As for the aquatic compartment, this was done by a combination exercise and not by a mathematical addition. The higher the final score number, the higher the expected amount of ENM in the soil (see Fig. 2).

sections.heading: 3.1. Conceptual approach
sections.text:
Recently, a grouping concept for metal and metal oxide nanomaterials with regard to their aquatic ecotoxicity was published (HundRinke et al., 2018). For that concept the criteria reactivity, ion release, morphology and ecotoxicity of the chemical composition (information from the bulk material) were identified as the most relevant ones for describing the nanomaterial's hazard. A weak point was the term “bulk” material. As there is no commonly accepted definition, every material, which is not covered by the definition for nanomaterials, should be a bulk material, even a material with a size of 101 nm. The objective of having the criterion “ecotoxicity of the bulk material” was to differentiate between the well-known toxic ENM such as Ag, CuO and ZnO
and the materials with significantly lower toxicity such as TiO2, SiO2 and CeO2. The ecotoxicity of ENM such as Ag, CuO and ZnO is based on the release of ions, but according to our results (see SI 1, Table S2) also SiO2 releases ions into the test medium in a similar order of magnitude as ZnO. Consequently, a differentiation between stable and ion-releasing ENM does not allow firm conclusions on ENM toxicity and is hence not predictive for hazard. To overcome the inaccuracy in the term “bulk material”, this criterion was replaced by “release of toxic ions”. However, to improve the clarity, esp. in figures, the term was reduced to “release of ions” and contrasted with “stable” ENM. Additionally, the approach developed by Hund-Rinke et al. (2018) was adapted to the above described procedure for fate scoring, in order to allow for a subsequent risk potential scoring. This requires a reduced amount of groups. Also, ENM attachment to aquatic organisms was included as additional parameter. This was based on the experimental observation that rather stable oxides were only toxic for algae, but the different subtypes of one ENM-type could differ significantly in the toxicity (e.g. factor 10 in the EC50 values of the 4 CeO2 ENM). But as this variation in toxicity was not reflected by variations in any of the considered PC-properties (see SI 1, Table S1 & 2) and toxicity due to turbidity in the test suspension followed by reduced light intensity for the growth of algae could be excluded, as additional property the “attachment of ENM to algae” was identified. This was supported by several reports on the relevance of ENM attachment for algae (Aruoja et al., 2015; Joonas et al., 2017; Ozkaleli and Erdem, 2018) and by own observations (unpublished results).
Furthermore, an expansion to the terrestrial compartment was implemented. In accordance to the fate scoring, for each criterion, two possible descriptions, namely “YES” and “NO” are proposed. “YES” means, the criterion is fulfilled, “NO” means, the criterion is not fulfilled. These “YES”/“NO” descriptions are transformed into the numerical scores “0” and “1”. Score “1”is given in case of fulfillment of the criterion as this results in a hazard for the considered environmental compartment. Score “0”is given in case the criterion is not fulfilled and thus, no hazard occurs.
For the development and evaluation of the risk scoring an existing data set on effect data on ENM was extended by testing further ENM in aquatic as well as terrestrial ecotoxicological standard tests. The ecotoxicological testing was accompanied by extensive physical-chemical characterization. In total, for the verification and refinement of the risk scoring approach a dataset of 25 NM could be used. A summary of all experimental procedures and the data sets obtained is available in SI 3 & 4.

sections.heading: 3.2. Hazard scoring for the aquatic compartment
sections.text:
For the aquatic compartment, four assessment criteria are taken into account. These are “release of ions”, “morphology”, “attachment of ENM” (for “stable” ENM, e.g. TiO2, CeO2, SiO2) and “reactivity” (for “ion releasing ENM”, e.g. Ag, ZnO, CuO), respectively. As ENM are either “stable” or “ion releasing”, finally three criteria are further combined into one single numerical aquatic hazard score. Table 5 presents an overview of the relevant criteria for the aquatic compartment and the respective suggested trigger values.
3.2.1. Suggestion of trigger values to enable ENM allocation to “YES” and “NO”
The decision regarding “release of toxic ions” is a qualitative assessment and based on expert judgement. This includes analyses on dissolution in the test media and the knowledge concerning the toxicity of the released ions.
For the parameter “morphology” small spherical ENM and fibers are separated from the other ENM such as larger spherical ENM and rods. For small spherical ENM a trigger value of 10 nm is proposed. This value is based on the finding of Ivask et al. (2014) who observed that the toxicity of Ag NMs with a size range of 20 to 80 nm differed

sections.heading: 3.2.2. Criteria aggregation by score combination
sections.text: The scores “0” and “1” for the properties “release of toxic ions”, “morphology” “attachment” and “reactivity” are combined into one single numerical final hazard score. The aquatic hazard scores are named “1” to “4” by definition and not by mathematical addition of the values “0” and “1”, and thus are the result of a combinatory exercise. The higher the score number, the higher the expected hazard. Specifically, “0 & 0 & 0” is the combination indicating the lowest hazard, whereas “1 & 1 & 1” indicates the highest hazard. A scheme for the deduction of the hazard score is presented in Fig. 3.

sections.heading: 3.2.3. Aquatic hazard scoring for 25 ENM
sections.text: Fig. 4 represents the final aquatic hazard scoring of 25 tested ENM (data are provided in SI 3, Table S5). To prove the consistency, for every ENM the ecotoxicological profile indicating the order of organisms sensitivity is listed. Additionally, for every hazard score the range of ecotoxicity of the ENMs within that score for the most sensitive organism is shown. It is obvious that the four hazard scores differ in the range of ecotoxicity although there is an overlap. Modifications of the same ENM resulting in different final scores (i.e. CeO2: NM-211, NM212, Eu doped – score 2; NM-213 – score 1, Fe2O3: nano_A, nano_B – score 2; _larger – score 1), differ by a factor of 10 in their ecotoxicity justifying their separation by different final scores. For TiO2 and Ag the relationship between final score, ecotoxicological profile and ecotoxicity is less obvious. CuPhthalo differs by the organic component from the other ENM being metals or metal oxides which could explain the different ecotoxicological profile. Furthermore, CuPhthalo is non-toxic in all used test systems which is in contrast to the other ENM. Metal and metal oxide ENM with hazard score 1 and 2 show identical ecotoxicological profiles, whereas for ENMs with hazard score 3, the ecotoxicological profiles vary. sections.heading: 4. Scoring of risk potential
sections.text:
The presented fate and hazard scoring yields 1 to 4 aquatic fate and hazard scores each, 1 to 4 terrestrial fate scores, and 1 and 2, respectively, terrestrial hazard scores. These scores are combined further into final aquatic and terrestrial risk scores. Again, this is a combinatory approach and not a mathematical exercise. Even though the authors are aware of the problems with ordinal scales as e.g. addressed by Hubbard and Evans (2010) it was decided to use such an approach, as it is pragmatic and easy to handle. Care needs to be taken with respect to transparency and interpretation of the final score numbers. In particular, this is true for the terrestrial risk scoring, as an imbalance exists with respect to the maximum achievable number of scores for fate and hazard. This imbalance reflects the current state-of-knowledge but cannot be resolved.
The mode of combining is shown in Figs. 7 and 8 for the aquatic and
terrestrial risk scoring. The results of the risk scoring are intended to allow a prioritization of ENMs for further action. For example, the scores guide which ENM should be tested in which degree of detail, or if modelling approaches may be sufficient.
Based on the fate scoring (Tables 1, 2) and hazard scoring (Figs. 4, 6), the following final risk scores were determined for the ENM.
In the aquatic compartment no ENM received the highest risk scores 10–8 (Fig. 9). The ENM with a high toxicity show a low fate score and hence a low concentration in the environmental compartment. Additionally no ENM received the lowest risk score 1, corresponding to low environmental ENM concentration as well as no ENM toxicity. The tested ENM received the risk scores between 2 and 7.
TiO2 ENM NM105, NM104 and Eu_doped received the highest risk score of 7. For these ENM a high concentration in the aquatic compartment is expected, whereas SiO2 ENM and ZnO NM113 received the lowest risk score of 2. For these ENM a low concentration and for SiO2 no toxicity is expected. For most ENM, different modifications of the materials show different risk scores. For example CeO2 NM211 received risk score 6, NM212 risk score 4, and NM213 risk score 3. In case different modifications of materials yield the same risk scores (i.e., modifications of TiO2, SiO2, and Fe2O3), these modifications also yield the same fate and hazard scores each.
These results demonstrate that a simple assessment which bases on the chemical composition can be problematic and misleading.
For the terrestrial compartment no ENM received the highest risk
scores 7 and 6 or the lowest risk score of 1. Among the tested materials, TiO2 NM105 and the CuPhthalo_nano received the highest final risk score of 5, whereas the materials nCu, CeO2 NM211 and Ag NM300K received the lowest risk score 2. The other ENM received risk score 4 and 3. The different morphology of the Fe2O3 nanomaterials did not affect the risk scoring. Both materials received the risk score 4 (Fig. 10). As for the water compartment, the different modifications of the metal and metal oxide ENM received different risk scores, e.g. CeO2 (NM211 – 3; NM212 NM213 – 4) or Cu (nCu – 3, CuO – 4, Cu phthalo_nano – 5). This confirms the results of the water compartment that a simple ranking based on the chemical composition would lead to wrong assumptions about potential risks.
For both the aquatic and the terrestrial risk scoring, the different Ag nanomaterials were allocated to different scores. This is due to the fact that for the terrestrial compartment allocation was driven by ion release, and by ion release and morphology for the aquatic compartment.
For the two compartments the risk scoring results in different prioritisations and order of the tested ENM. However, for both compartments the TiO2 NM105 received the highest risk score, mainly triggered by its high persistence in the two compartments.

sections.heading: 5. Discussion
sections.text:
Strategies for environmental risk prioritization or risk screening of engineered nanomaterials (ENM) are needed in order to reduce time and cost consuming in depth material testing (Oomen et al., 2015). Various risk screening methods for ENM already exist, however, most of them aim at occupational and human health risk (see Arvidsson et al. (2016)). For the environment, however, much less work has been done in this direction. Therefore, this study aims at providing a concept for a risk potential scoring/risk screening method, which combines information for environmental fate and hazard of ENM under the perspective of risk evaluation. The scoring method may for example be used in research prioritization for NM developers and producers as well as to support safe-by-design.
The only work that considers risk prioritization with emphasis on the environment is the “early warning signs” concept developed by (Hansen et al., 2013). Our approach differs from that in extending the set of criteria and in focussing on quantifiable criteria. Furthermore, an approach for environmental hazard grouping of ENMs has already been proposed (Hund-Rinke et al., 2018). This approach is focussing on the aquatic environment and is rather complex by yielding 12 hazard groups. However, the ENM fate in the environment finds no consideration in this approach.
Hence, the innovation of the approach reported here comprises of the following subjects:
i. The early warning signs concept is extended with respect to quantitatively describable and ENM-specific criteria.
ii. The existing grouping system for environmental hazard is simplified to be useful for scoring.
iii. A novel scoring approach for ENM environmental fate is established.

fate, and also in the organisms living in the compartments, separate approaches for the terrestrial and aquatic environment are developed. vi. A case study on up to 25 ENM proved the applicability of the proposed scheme.
As mentioned, a crucial perspective of risk ranking is a fine adjusted balance of “as little input data as possible and as much as necessary” to obtain robust ranking results. With other words, it was the aim of the developed scoring scheme to keep the data requirements as low as possible, but as precise and comprehensive as necessary. For that reason for example no kinetic information is required, as these measurements are quite laborious. The development of risk scoring concepts using
literature data has been difficult as there are multiple modifications of the applied test designs and ENM which can affect the results and hence the conclusions regarding risk (Lynch et al., 2014). Literature reviews such as presented by Bondarenko et al. (2013) and Simonin and Richaume (2015) show the variability in results. Therefore, a homogenous data set is indispensable.
This was achieved by various decisions and strategies. For example, systematic and comprehensive sets on PC data describing fate and hazard are desirable. However, having in mind the high complexity of fate processes, which are not describable by mono-causal correlations, it is a more straightforward strategy to experimentally determine the fate processes than to rely on literature data. Thus, we decided to use the results of reliable transformation and mobility studies to derive cut-off values which allow for the decision between “YES” and “NO” (the criterion is fulfilled/not fulfilled).
A second example for simplification and condensing is our strategy for the hazard scoring approach. The environmental hazard scoring scheme is based on a grouping approach introduced by Hund-Rinke et al. (2017). Focus of the grouping approach was to predict effects for a “target” substance with information gaps by using data from a similar “source” substance. Thus, ENM with comparable relevant PC-properties are allocated to the same group. In contrast, the presented scheme aims at a hazard ranking expressed by scores. The score number in turn is a result of the number of PC-parameters indicating the ENM's ecotoxicity. This means, the higher the number of PC-parameters indicating ecotoxicity, the higher the hazard score regardless the identity of the PCparameters.
A further example for the pragmatism of our approach is the fact that the criteria each used for the aquatic and terrestrial compartment are not completely identical. The selected criteria described best the fate and ecotoxicological effects in the respective compartments. However, this leads to imbalances of the number of criteria for fate and hazard ranking. In particular in the terrestrial compartment, the number of fate criteria by far exceeds the number of hazard criteria. We accepted the fact that the ranking result is dominated by fate. However, the situation reflects the current state-of-knowledge on ENM effects on terrestrial organisms and thus was not resolved.
Last but not least, any concept of risk scoring is an example for simplification. Generally, in risk assessment strategies risk is defined as quotient of environmental concentration and hazard (ECHA, 2016). While several methodologies are established to assess workplace exposures (respirable mass or number concentration) (Asbach et al., 2017; Kuempel et al., 2012), the analysis of ENMs in the environment is still a challenge (Nowack et al., 2015). This is because of the interactions with the complex environmental matrices. In contrast, the risk scoring approach considers only the properties of an ENM. The approach is independent of the intended use of the ENM, the release scenarios and possible geographic differences in the environmental concentration. It can easily be applied even if such information is not available.
The risk prioritization was applied to 20 (aquatic compartment) and 16 (terrestrial compartment) ENMs, respectively. The above discussed balance of “as little input data as possible and as much as necessary” was obviously attained, as a sufficiently broad ranking range was observed. Databases to derive cut-off values for the “YES”/“NO” – decisions seem to be comprehensive enough as interpretable results are obtained. In particular it is worth mentioning that the scoring system is capable to differentiate between different subtypes of the same ENM, such as CeO2 NM212 is characterized by score 4, whereas CeO2 NM211 is assigned to score 6 as well as ZnO NM113 is characterized by score 3 and NM111, 112 by score 4. Such a result confirms the statement that a simple ranking, which is exclusively based on the chemical composition would lead to false conclusions about potential risks. Despite the meaningful and promising results the scoring system obviously yields, it has so far the limitation that the ENM dataset which was used to test the performance of the risk scoring system was the same as the training data set used to derive cut-off values for the “YES”/“NO” – decision.
Thus, any further, independent test data will allow fully verifying or falsifying the selected parameters, the trigger values and the approach in general.
The risk ranking table can be used for further decisions and actions. Starting with the high risk score ENMs, it needs to be clarified whether high fate scores or high hazard scores contributed more to the allocation. For the high score segment further and in-depth testing is the method of choice. E.g., for ENMs with high fate scores, complex fate studies in larger soil columns, in water/sediment-systems or even mesocosm studies might be appropriate. For ENMs with high hazard scores ecotoxicological tests also using other than standard test organisms and endpoints might be helpful. For the medium score segment modelling approaches might be appropriate. For the low score segment no action is needed in the first instance.

sections.heading: 6. Conclusion
sections.text:
The scoring of ENM regarding their environmental risk with the aim of risk prioritization was demonstrated to be possible by using the proposed parameters. By the separate consideration of fate and hazard, a meaningful combination into risk scores for the terrestrial and aquatic compartment was achieved. This was concluded based on the allocation of several ENM and their subtypes into the scoring scheme and the result that subtypes could indeed be separated due to allocation to different scores. It is therefore possible to describe the fate and hazard at least of metal and metal oxide ENM by a combination of ENM specific criteria and PC-properties.
The risk scoring approach only focuses on the selected ENM properties and environmental processes and thus is independent of the uncertainties regarding the environmental concentration.
Still there is room for improvement, e.g. regarding the trigger values which have to be verified or falsified by a test data set. Furthermore, the scoring scheme was tested for metal and metal oxide ENM. For other types of ENM such as carbon based or organic ENM clarification with regard to the applicability of the schemes is needed. Probably, the selected criteria and PC-properties have to be modified for other material classes.
With increasing knowledge a future extension and specification of the proposed schemes for ENM environmental fate and hazard is anticipated. This also includes, e.g., the consideration of sediment as environmental compartment. Furthermore, not only larger data sets are needed, but also improvements in methodology are required to determine PC parameters (e.g. reactivity) as well as biological endpoints (e.g. attachment). This is specifically important for the derivation of the cut-off values.
Certainly, the approach can be used retrospectively to decide on further actions for already existing ENM because of their relative environmental risk potential unless a comprehensive risk assessment can be performed as more information on fate, ecotoxicity and environmental concentration is available. Whether it also can be used prospectively for product development needs further investigation. It has to be investigated whether such a condensed approach provides sufficient information in the scope of product development.

metadata.abstractText: Engineered nanomaterials (ENM) have a widespread presence in human life and are components of many products and applications. This warrants an easy and fast evaluation of potential environmental risks. However, so far this is hampered by the multitude of different nanomaterials on the markets in addition to the many variations in form, size and surface modifications. Testing of each variation of ENM is not manageable, and hence the development and application of fast risk screening tools for ENMs is discussed. Here, we present the development of a scoring scheme with regard to ENM environmental risks under consideration of the two compartments water and soil. It allows for the ranking of ENM according to their environmental fate and hazard by taking into account criteria that are meaningful and relevant for ENM. The selection of the criteria is based on conceptual considerations, existing knowledge, and experimental work including transport and transformation studies as well as aquatic and terrestrial toxicity tests. The allocation of the ENM to the scores informs on the potential for transport and transformation and the hazard potential. Fate and hazard scores are subsequently combined into one risk score (1–10 for aquatic compartment, 1–7 for terrestrial compartment). The risk score has the intention to indicate which ENM may need prioritization for further action, i.e. with regard to the degree of detail for further testing or modelling. The applicability and consistency of the scoring schemes were assessed by taking different chemical species (e.g. of Ag, TiO2, SiO2, Cu, Fe) of ENM in various modifications (e.g. different shapes and coatings) into account. In conclusion, the established scoring schemes were found to be applicable to rank ENM according to their environmental fate and hazard potential, and thus to their environmental risk potential.
